data.title: [Feature Request] Interactive terminal for interacting with variables in memory
data.body:
I am using vscode mainly for machine learning applications with python. I have added the python extension by Don Jayamanne for this purpose. This is a code for loading iris dataset into memory

```
from sklearn.datasets import load_iris
import torch as to
from torch.autograd import Variable

iris=load_iris()
X=iris.data
Y=iris.target
print X.shape
```
and on execution gets this output in terminal
```
ubu:~$ python /home/ubu/Desktop/torch/iris.py
(150, 4)
```
I work with many datasets and variables and I always double check all the variables which I am working with. In Spyder we can check every variables and functions directly using the terminal without using the editor window.

But we cant do similar interaction with vscode terminal
```
USER:~$python
>>> X.shape
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
NameError: name 'X' is not defined
```

A temporary solution which I found is to write a *print* code in the editor and run the line and it will print the result. But this is becoming a painful chore after some time.

data.title: editor appears off-screen after rearranging desktops in "display settings"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. drag the visual studio code editor to the left desktop on a two-monitor system with the leftmost desktop as "desktop 2" as labeled under "settings"->"display settings"
2. close visual studio code
2. go to "settings"->"display settings" and click-drag "desktop 2" to be on the right of desktop 1
3. open visual studio code. it appears off-screen where desktop 2 used to be. to get it on-screen, window-tab + right-click editor + snap-right works, but is obviously not ideal.

data.title: Persistent warning about Spring preloader process in Rails projects
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0 - Extensions: |Extension|Author|Version| |---|---|---| |EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.9.3| |beautify|HookyQR|1.1.1| |vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.16| |git-easy|bibhasdn|1.9.1| |react-redux-react-router-snippets|discountry|0.2.4| |vscode-new-file|dkundel|3.0.2| |githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0| |gitlens|eamodio|4.1.2| |ruby|groksrc|0.0.6| |ruby-rubocop|misogi|0.3.5| |cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.4| |rails-run-spec-vscode|noku|0.0.9| |Ruby|rebornix|0.12.1| |vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.9.0| |vscode-fileutils|sleistner|2.6.2| |vim|vscodevim|0.8.6| |vscode-react-native|vsmobile|0.3.2|; --- I'm not sure if this issue is best reported in the main Github repo for VSCode or rather belongs to one of the extensions. Regardless, this issue is negatively affecting my development experience with VSCode on my Rails projects and, due to its high frequency of occurrence and how annoying it is, prevents me from being able to use VSCode as the IDE for my Rails projects. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a **Rails** project that uses **Spring** in VSCode 2. Open any `.rb` file. This problem will manifest in every `.rb` file that I open. 3. An error message saying `Error: Running via Spring preloader in process XXXX` (where XXXX is a process number) appears. The message will not go away unless I press Close. See this screenshot:

data.title: Indentation of tree view item label changes when adding icon

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create custom tree view extension with icons and observe padding of label.
2. It is impossible to have icons and re-create the layout of the built-in explorer.

In the first picture, in the "Git Context" custom tree view (this is an experiment from myself, not released on the market yet), it looks like the `.gitignore` entry belongs to the folder above, but in fact it doesn't.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/530988/27264255-740381fc-5472-11e7-8e01-7e3cca9db5d3.png)

Without icons, the layout is correct:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/530988/27264263-9ad1802c-5472-11e7-8329-5c56701d572e.png)

EDIT: I just noticed that the "minimal" icon theme of vs code has folder icons and then adjusts the padding accordingly:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/530988/27264347-54cd23a4-5474-11e7-8fb6-b5723765f847.png)

data.title: Terminal selection cursor position is not ideal
data.body:
Currently selecting anywhere on a character will put the "cursor" (ie. selection start) at the left of the character. Instead it should do that when the mouse is on the left side of the character, and when it's on the right side start it on the right side.

Upstream issue: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/709

data.title: Terminal: Double clicking dragging should select up to the word at the mouse
data.body:
Currently up to the character is selected. See https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/716

Upstream issue: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/697

data.title: Autocomplete popup reproduces jsdoc line breaks verbatim
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

JSDoc comments are parsed correctly for display in tooltips when hovering over a variable, but not when displayed during autocompletion. Line breaks are required for longer descriptions in order to read JSDoc comments without requiring word wrap, but are treated as hard line breaks in the autocompletion popup.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/298883/27263249-d726e2a2-54a8-11e7-9728-61ff3c7dc2dc.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/298883/27263252-e8d47474-54a8-11e7-9c54-3e72b7ecc46a.png)

data.title: A lot of tscancellation files in temp dir
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 73015a5
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use vscode

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/461084/27263172-70c62bee-543a-11e7-9f9b-7d2e5042b452.png)

I was noticing vscode disk usage way high, and found that it's creating `vscode-tscancellation` files in TEMP non-stop. Have over 500 files in my temp dir in after 2 days working on TS projects

data.title: Double click to select a word in terminal should exclude several characters
data.body:
Many compilers wrap a path in brackets, ls -lR add a colon at the end of the path etc. We don't want to select these extra characters when double clicking.

Upstream issue https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/713

data.title: Problems generated by valid non-relative references in Angular/TypeScript
data.body:
I'm using VS Code 1.13.1 with TypeScript 2.3.4 and the following Angular versions: angular/cli: 1.1.1 node: 8.1.2 angular/common: 4.2.2 angular/core: 4.2.2 angular/compiler: 4.2.2 angular/compiler-cli: 4.2.2 Two extensions are installed: - Angular Language Service 0.1.3 - Debugger for Chrome 3.1.4 I have a simple Component: import { Component, OnInit } from '@angular/core'; import { AuthService } from 'app/core/auth/auth.service'; @Component({ selector: 'app-login', templateUrl: './login.component.html', styleUrls: ['./login.component.css'] }) export class LoginComponent implements OnInit { constructor( private auth: AuthService ) { } ngOnInit() { } } With a simple template:

Welcome to sandbox!





The code compiles just fine in the VS Code Terminal window, and it executes exactly as expected, however I get this error in the "Problems" tab: > file: > 'file:///c%3A/code/sandbox/src/app/core/login/login.component.ts' > severity: 'Error' message: 'Error encountered resolving symbol values > statically. Could not resolve app/core/auth/auth.service relative to > c:/code/sandbox/src/app/core/login/login.component.ts.' at: '4,2' > source: 'Angular' If I change the imports to this the error disappears: import { AuthService } from '../auth/auth.service'; Using non-relative paths is valid Angular/TypeScript syntax (it's discussed in the TypeScript Handbook and used in examples in the Angular Routing Guide). Again, the non-relative path also compiles and runs. This doesn't seem to happen everywhere, only in Components. I can use non-relative paths in the app.module.ts file and there are no Problems raised there.

data.title: Allow to split editor vertically via context menu
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063

it took me a while today to realise the reason I couldn't get 'side-by-side' file views was because the 'editor group layout' was set to vertically stacked.  To be fair the 'split editor' icon does change according to which mode you're in but it's a bit subtle. Why not provide a right-click context menu on the 'split editor' button to allow a switch?

data.title: Exception UI not showing in debug adaptor
data.body:
VSCode 1.13
DAP: 1.20

I'm trying to include support for the big red Exception UI in my debug adaptor, but for some reason nothing is being displayed.

I've added `supportsExceptionInfoRequest` into `initializeRequest()` and my `exceptionInfoRequest()` method gets called correctly after a `StoppedEvent` with reason: 'exception'.

But nothing is displayed on screen. As a test, my `exceptionInfoRequest` method looks like this:

```
    exceptionInfoRequest(response, args) {

        response.body = {
            exceptionId: "anExceptionId",
            description: "description",
            breakMode: 'always',
            details: {
                message: "exception message",
                typeName: "ExceptionTypeName",
                fullTypeName: "ExceptionFullTypeName",
                evaluateName: "evaluateName",
                stackTrace: "stackTrace",
                innerException: [],
            }
        };    
        this.sendResponse(response);
    }

```

The code breaks as expected on the exception, the above function is called correctly and the call stack is also displayed correctly, but no Exception UI is displayed.

![a](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13035517/27261280-178cd2f0-5438-11e7-879e-1d4c9ad74635.png)


Is there some flag/variable/setting that I'm missing? 
Alternatively, can someone point me to the relevant code sections in the vscode source so I can try and figure out why nothing is appearing.

data.title: Select multiple tabs with Ctrl+Click & Shift+Click to drag and drop them between splitted editors
data.body:
Requesting a capability to select multiple tabs with <kbd>Ctrl+Click</kbd> (to add a single tab to the selection) and <kbd>Shift+Click</kbd> (to add a range of tabs to the selection) and to drag and drop them between splitted editors.

Motivation: Right now `Split Editor` leaves the tabs at the left side and clone the currently opened tab to the right side. If one wants to have all or some of the tabs at the right side he has to drag them manually one by one. It would be great to have an option to select some of them and quickly drag and drop to the other side.

data.title: Request feature "Split Integrated Terminal"
data.body: It would be great if we can split rather than switch between multiple shells within integrated terminal just like how we split editor!

data.title: Problem checker incorrectly adds undefined possibility to a type in a lambda
Add support to open `.bib` files on Windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a `.bib` file on Windows.
2. Double click the file to open it.
3. Note that Visual Studio Code does not show up as option to open the file.

It looks like #909 added BibTex to the language identifiers, but I don't think that made Visual Studio Code tell the OS it can open `.bib` files.

data.title: Underline broken require paths
data.body:
Sometimes when refactoring and moving around files in modular codebase you end up with a lot of broken files paths. Would be great help to see at a glance if a require points to location that actually is there. Maybe underline it with red.

It's really cool how I can hover a path while holding cmd to see if it's a real path, but I can't see the broken paths at a glance.

data.title: Improve grammar of config setting description
data.body:
This PR changes the `config.enableSmartCommit` setting description from

```
Commit all changes when there are not staged changes.
```

to

```
Commit all changes when there are no staged changes.
```

While the former version is technically correct, I consider the proposed version easier to read.

data.title: Scroll position not retained when switching back to a file that was opened from the source control diff section
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.13.1 (1.13.1)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. open the diff view for any file from the Source Control panel
2. click the Open File button at the top-right corner of vscode
3. scroll to a different position in the file (doesn't matter if the cursor is also at the new position or the old position)
4. switch to a different file then back.

**What I saw:** the scroll position is back to where it was when the file was originally opened from the diff view.
**Expected:** the new scroll position should have been preserved; just like it does if the file was opened from the Explorer (or CMD+P)

Reproducible when vscode is started with extensions disabled.


**GIF of the bug:**
The cursor is moved from the initial line no.1577 to line no.1495. After switching back to this file, we are back to line no. 1577.
![issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11534188/27259414-9985f6f4-5430-11e7-8291-721910dc9a0d.gif)

data.title: Don't assume .txt (nor .gitignore) when newly saving a text file on Windows
data.body:
Version 1.13.0-insider
Commit f977399d58f7b64db35047fafe0c6e59e15f11d5
Date 2017-06-02T10:54:04.063Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0

When I create a new file, write something into it and then save it, it more often than not gets an unwanted extension, in this case `.txt`, because I forgot to use doublequotes. Especially for plain text files this makes no sense.

This is because you set the default file type for the Windows file save dialog to `*.txt;*.gitignore` which means that everything works fine if I specify a filename ending with either `.txt` or `.gitignore`, but for everything else, `.txt` is appended. This is annoying when creating files like `.env`, `.jshintrc`, `.editorconfig`, `Makefile`, `Dockerfile`, and so on or files where no language exists in VSCode (or is not installed), e.g. `test.csv` or `nginx.conf`. To save such files, one has to use doublequotes, e.g. `".env"`.

I would suggest not setting a file extension in the file save dialog at all for plain text files.

data.title: Add option to hide notification of  "There is an available update"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (`376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf`, 2017-06-08T16:41:25.571Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.11.4-100.fc24.x86_64
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|contextualduplicate|lafe|0.2.0|
|MDTools|seanmcbreen|1.0.1|
|change-case|wmaurer|1.0.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I install the app via DNF (or Yum for older Fedora) (from Microsoft repository).
2. Whenever there is new update, the app shows a notification of: _"There is an available update."_
3. I already checked 2 last updates. The app always got new version from somewhere. But `sudo dnf update` didn't see nothing from Microsoft repository. Only after some days it would be able to download new update from the repo.

So would you please add option to hide the notification _"There is an available update"_? I'm sorry but it's really annoying  `:-(`

Thank you,
